title: Eva Gustavson
text:
Eva Gustavson (18 February 1917 – 10 February 2009), sometimes known as Eva Gustafson, was a <a href="Norwegian-American">Norwegian-American</a> <a href="contralto">contralto</a> who had an active international performance career in <a href="opera">opera</a>s and concerts during the 1940s and 1950s. She later embarked on a second career as a voice teacher in the United States, notably teaching for many years on the music faculty of the <a href="University%20of%20Southern%20California">University of Southern California</a>.
Background.
Eva Gustavson was born in <a href="Horten">Horten</a> on the <a href="Oslo%20Fjord">Oslo Fjord</a>, in <a href="Norway">Norway</a>. Her father, Oscar Gustavson, was a violinist-conductor at the <a href="National%20Theatre%2C%20Oslo">National Theatre</a> and later at <a href="Oslo%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">Oslo Philharmonic Orchestra</a>; her mother, Margit Gustavson (née Schwartz), played the piano and was an organist. Eva studied singing and dancing in her youth, becoming an accomplished tap-dancer, acrobat, and musician. She joined a traveling cabaret troupe in her late teens but was later advised to quit in order to pursue a career as an opera singer. She studied singing in Oslo with <a href="Bokken%20Lasson">Bokken Lasson</a>, <a href="Soffi%20Sch%C3%B8nning">Soffi Schønning</a> and <a href="Signe%20Amundsen">Signe Amundsen</a>. During the early part of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, she entered the <a href="Stockholm%20Opera">Stockholm Opera</a> School in neutral <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> on a scholarship where she studied under <a href="Adelaide%20von%20Skilondz">Adelaide von Skilondz</a>. She was also mentored during this time by <a href="Kirsten%20Flagstad">Kirsten Flagstad</a>. She became separated from her family for the duration of much of the war, as they were stranded by the <a href="Occupation%20of%20Norway%20by%20Nazi%20Germany">Occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany</a>. After the War, Gustavson continued with further studies in <a href="Milan">Milan</a>, <a href="Italy">Italy</a> under the advice of Flagstad. She later studied the title role of "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>" in California with <a href="Vladimir%20Rosing">Vladimir Rosing</a>.
Career.
Gustavson made her professional opera debut in <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a> in 1946. In 1947 she won first prize at the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> international music competition in <a href="Paris">Paris</a>. In 1947-1948 she was a principal contralto at the <a href="Op%C3%A9ra%20Royal%20de%20Wallonie">Opéra Royal de Wallonie</a> and made several appearances at <a href="La%20Monnaie">La Monnaie</a> in <a href="Brussels%2C%20Belgium">Brussels, Belgium</a>. She spent the next 15 years performing lead roles in major <a href="opera%20house">opera house</a>s throughout Europe and North America. She became particularly associated with the title role in <a href="Georges%20Bizet">Georges Bizet</a>'s "<a href="Carmen">Carmen</a>", a role she portrayed more than 300 times during her career in multiple languages. Her first portrayal of Carmen was in 1949 at the <a href="Royal%20Swedish%20Opera">Royal Swedish Opera</a>. Her other signature roles were Amneris in <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="Aida">Aida</a>" and Azucena in Verdi's "<a href="Il%20trovatore">Il trovatore</a>". Although she appeared in operas and toured throughout Europe and North America, Gustavson spent much of her career performing with the <a href="Norwegian%20National%20Opera">Norwegian National Opera</a> in <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a>.
Immigration.
In 1949 Gustavson immigrated to the United States. That same year she gave what is probably her best known performance, the role of Amneris in <a href="Arturo%20Toscanini">Arturo Toscanini</a>'s 1949 concert telecast and recording of <a href="Giuseppe%20Verdi">Giuseppe Verdi</a>'s "<a href="A%C3%AFda">Aïda</a>" with the <a href="NBC%20Symphony%20Orchestra">NBC Symphony Orchestra</a>, and <a href="Herva%20Nelli">Herva Nelli</a> in the title role. <a href="Richard%20Tucker%20%28tenor%29">Richard Tucker</a> was Radames. In the mid-1950s she settled on the West Coast of the United States, raised a family, and continued to appear in concert, including a performance of <a href="Stravinsky">Stravinsky</a>’s "<a href="Le%20Rossignol">Le Rossignol</a>" under the baton of the composer. Gustavson also taught on the voice faculty of the <a href="University%20of%20Southern%20California">University of Southern California</a> for seventeen years. In 1977 she was honored by the <a href="King%20of%20Norway">King of Norway</a> with the <a href="Royal%20Norwegian%20Order%20of%20St.%20Olav">Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav</a>. She published an autobiography entitled "Shooting Star From Dovrehallen to Toscanini, and then San Pedro". Gustavson died in <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">San Pedro, Los Angeles, California</a>, one week before her 92nd birthday.
